comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: Overblown slightly diffuse darkened copy with reversed wording from identification stamp on reverse side. A-3B Skywarrior Bu No 147650 VAH-2 Modex 601 Large squadron insignia aft of cockpit. Tail code NL CVW-9 USS CORAL SEA Equipped as air refuelling tanker. Go here for a color picture of A-3B Skywarrior 147650 as marked in 'flickr' pic above. geta-o.maxs.jp/USMIL/A/A-3/A-3B/A-3B.htm geta-o.maxs.jp/USMIL/A/A-3/A-3B/A-3b(nl601)147650-sd7.jpg VAH-2 "ROYAL RAMPANTS" 147650/NL601 1962.04.05/ATSUGI (5 April 1962 over NAF Atsugi, Japan) [year may be incorrect] Go here for a large color profile of A-3B Skywarrior 147650 as marked in 'flickr' pic above. wp.scn.ru/en/ww3/b/796/3/1/2 Seen wearing the markings VAH-2, this Skywarrior is shown as it would have appeared in 1965, on board the CVA-43 USS Coral Sea in the Gulf of Tonkin. At this time, it was configured as an A-3B bomber/tanker. This aircraft crashed on October 6th, 1966 after midair collision with RA-5C. Artist: unknown Source: "Military Aircraft of the Cold War", General editor: Jim Winchester. The Aviation Factfile, (c) 2006 International Masters Publishers BV, ISBN-10: 1-84013-929-3; ISBN-13: 978-1-84013-929-7. Some notes on A-3B Skywarrior 147650 Originally built as A3D-2 Accepted by US Navy April 1960 Became A-3B from 1962 Was one of those aircraft able to act as an airborne tanker before conversion of a large proportion of the Skywarrior fleet A-3B Skywarrior 147650 was tragically lost on Oct. 6, 1966 following a mid-air collision with an RA-5C Vigilante while both were in formation on approach to CVN-65 USS Enterprise off Southern California. A record of the incident here: www.a3skywarrior.com/memorial/full_accident_date.htm Midair with RA-5C (RVAH 7) The KA-3B joined RA-5C on starboard wing for a section CCA penetration from marshall point. (Carrier-Controlled Approach) During transition to landing configuration, the KA-3B hit the RA-5C's right side. Both aircraft plunged into sea. Skywarriors were never equipped with ejection seats. The RA-5C crew successfully ejected. The A-3B crew were lost. A-3B 147650 crew; Pilot; Lt Deighton Hunt BN; Ensign Carroll Gibson 3rdCM; AO1 Melvin Colby Detailed report taken from text of this website recording USS Enterprise history 1966 to 1970: www.history.navy.mil/danfs/e4/enterprise-viiib.htm The ship conducted additional drills and air exercises (3–12 October 1966), a period punctuated by tragedy. At 2215 on that day, Flare 102, an RA-5C Vigilante (BuNo 149288), Lieutenant John K. Sutor, pilot, and Lieutenant (jg) Peter C. Carrothers, radar navigator, RVAH-7, launched from Enterprise on a night reconnaissance mission. Flare 102 climbed to 21,500 feet and returned overhead to attempt to rendezvous with Folder III, the KA-3B duty tanker (BuNo 147650), Lieutenant Deighton A. Hunt, pilot, Ensign Carroll L. Gibson, bombardier/navigator, and AO1 Melvin F. Colby, crewman/navigator, attached to VAH-2 Det M, for inflight refueling practice. Enterprise advised Flare 102 that they were “experiencing difficulty” contacting Folder 111, requesting that the Vigilante connect with the tanker. The two aircraft rendezvoused, Sutor joining Hunt on his starboard wing. At 2315, Flare 102 assumed the lead and was vectored to the marshal point. A section penetration was initiated at 2331. The aircraft each entered the overcast at 1,700 feet, 10 NM astern of the ship, transitioning to level flight at 1,200 feet, 175 KIAS. During the transition to the landing configuration at approximately 2352, at the eight-mile rate, in straight and level flight, they collided, Folder 111 “apparently” striking the Vigilante on the starboard side. Flare 102 rolled to the left in a “nose down” attitude, Sutor shouting to Carrothers to “eject!” Both men were rescued by one of the carrier’s helos and returned to Enterprise, but an “immediate and thorough” search and rescue (SAR) by aircraft from NAS North Island, backed-up by the Coast Guard, failed to locate any survivors from Folder 111. My respects to both crews, their families and friends.

comment.author: 108461309@N08
comment._content:
The Links to the color photos do not work does any one have the  color picture of  A-3B Skywarrior 147650 my dad was the third crewman on board that day thanks in advance
Fred Colby

comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: Hello sir, thank you for a most honourable request. please try the following current internet links and a color image of the aircraft will be found easily look for the very first picture titled "147650/NL601 1962.04.05/ATSUGI" geta-o.jp/USMIL/A/A-3/A-3B/A-3B.htm as it's a Japanese website a good search engine should provide a modicum of translation either click on the image to bring it up on a separate page or copy the following to a search engine direct - as the link is playing up: geta-o.jp/USMIL/A/A-3/A-3B/A-3b(nl601)147650-sd7.jpg as it is published on open view it may be saved as a picture file and a color print made - or copied to a Microsoft Word file then reduced to fit the A4 size page and the notes from my comment simply copied from the screen and added to it. I am glad to be of service in my humble way.

comment.author: 108461309@N08
comment._content:
AceFlyboy1 thank you so much for the link  I try to gather as much as I can on my dad, i was just 2 1/2 years old when his aircraft went down   and this is the only way I can remember and Honor  him
thank you so much again
 Fred Colby ( Melvin F Colby III)
